explanation: The report is not proven correct. Rule 8.13 recommends that pointers point to const-qualified types when that is feasible for the overall design, but the supplied snippet alone does not demonstrate that the members are immutable everywhere. In the struct MHD_HTTP_Res_Header the members are declared as char *header and char *value; converting those declarations to const char * would only be required if none of the codebase ever modifies the pointed-to buffers. The shown function only reads those members (and returning pos->value as const char * is legal and good practice), but a single read-only use does not prove the object can be made const globally. Without examining all creation/assignment/modification sites for header/value, you cannot conclude a MISRA 8.13 violation. If, after a whole-program review, header/value are never modified after initialization, then the struct should be updated to use const char * to comply with 8.13. As reported, there is insufficient evidence, so the claim is not correct.
